properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Wind chill values near -45 are expected tonight into early Wednesday. Clear skies and moderate winds under a very cold air mass will allow temperatures to drop into the low minus thirties tonight with wind chill values near -45. Temperatures will moderate Wednesday morning. ### Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-16T08:19:15-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-15T16:20:15-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3099254344.2020
Area: Fort Severn, Peawanuck
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall may occur on Thursday. Locations: southern Nova Scotia. Time span: Beginning Thursday morning and ending late Thursday evening. Remarks: There is considerable uncertainty as to the amount of snowfall these regions will receive. However, current indications are that 15 centimetres of snowfall or more may fall before the snow ends late Thursday evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-16T06:40:49-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall, blowing snow and strong winds are forecast. Additional snowfall amounts: 10 to 25 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northwesterly 80 to 100 km/h. Locations: the west coast of Newfoundland. Time span: until Wednesday afternoon or evening. Remarks: as temperatures fall below freezing this evening, snow will combine with strong winds to reduce visibility in blowing snow. Occasional to frequent whiteout conditions are likely, especially over exposed areas where blowing snow will be more intense. Strongest wind gusts will occur over the Port au Port Peninsula and areas south to Channel-Port aux Basques. Winds will begin to weaken on Wednesday morning. Conditions will begin to improve for some areas on Wednesday afternoon as snow changes to flurries, which will eventually taper off overnight on Wednesday night. Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-12-16T11:15:39-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-15T19:16:39-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0875722285.2020
Area: Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity, Corner Brook and vicinity, Gros Morne, Bay St. George, Parson's Pond - Hawke's Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: High water levels expected. Locations: eastern Newfoundland. Time span: Wednesday to Thursday. Remarks: Higher than normal water levels are likely during the high tide of Wednesday morning and possible during Thursday morning due to a combination of storm surge and large waves. At this time, the chance of any significant coastal flooding remains low. However, a change in atmospheric conditions could result in the need for a storm surge warning for coastal areas. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-12-16T11:14:07-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-15T19:15:07-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1564549786.2020

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Storm Surge Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Warning of potential breaking sea conditions and overwash issued jointly by Fisheries and Oceans Canada (Science) and the Meteorological Service of Canada - Quebec Region on 2020-12-15. Higher than normal water levels and large waves are expected near the coast this afternoon. An intense low pressure system near Newfoundland will cause very strong to high winds over the regions listed below. The combination of these winds and the fact that we are currently in a period of high tidal range might give minor flooding along coastlines in the vicinity of the following locality on the date and at the times specified (eastern standard time). Kamouraska - Rivière-du-Loup - Trois-Pistoles: 2020-12-15, from 01:00 PM to 04:30 PM. Rimouski - Mont-Joli: 2020-12-15, from 12:30 PM to 04:00 PM. Matane: 2020-12-15, from 12:30 PM to 04:00 PM. Sainte-Anne-des-Monts - Grande-Vallée: 2020-12-15, from 12:00 PM to 03:30 PM. ### Coastal erosion is possible in vulnerable areas. Storm surge warnings are issued when water levels pose a threat to coastal regions. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-15T23:59:52-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-15T16:10:52-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0304928599.2020
Area: Mont-Joli area, Le Bic - Rimouski area, Matane, Grande-Vallée area, Sainte-Anne-des-Monts area, Trois-Pistoles area, Kamouraska area, Rivière-du-Loup area

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Additional snowfall amounts: 5 to 10 cm. Locations: the Great Northern Peninsula. Time span: until early Wednesday morning. Remarks: Temperatures are expected to remain near the freezing mark throughout the whole event, resulting in blowing snow occurring only in exposed areas. Conditions will improve for most areas Wednesday morning as snow tapers to flurries. However, areas on the western side of the peninsula, south of Plum Point, will likely see some further accumulations during the day Wednesday from more persistent flurries. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall may occur on Thursday. Locations: most of mainland Nova Scotia Time span: Beginning Thursday morning and ending early Friday morning. Remarks: There is considerable uncertainty as to the amount of snowfall these regions will receive. However, current indications are that there is the potential for accumulations greater than 15 cm to occur in some areas of mainland Nova Scotia Thursday. As with most storms that pass south of Nova Scotia, a small difference in the forecast track will could result in a significant change in the snowfall forecast. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Flurries, snowsqualls, and blowing snow are expected to continue. Total snowfall: in excess of 30 centimetres by Wednesday evening. Maximum wind gusts: 70 to 90 km/h. Locations: western Cape Breton. Time span: tonight and Wednesday. Remarks: snowfall rates will begin to diminish through the day on Wednesday as the winds begin to ease. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Snow squall warnings are issued when bands of snow form that produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. An Arctic air mass combined with moderate winds will generate wind chill values near minus 38 over Northwestern Quebec tonight. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions are expected to develop this afternoon as wind speeds increase. The strongest winds, with gusts between 80 and 90 km/h, will occur this evening then weaken after midnight. Visibility in blowing snow will improve tonight. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
